predictions.text: Nvidia will publicly announce a definitive agreement to acquire Groq (company or material assets/IP), with disclosed or reliably reported transaction value of at least $10 billion, by 2026-02-28 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if Nvidia issues a press release, SEC 8-K, or equivalent investor communication announcing a signed definitive agreement to acquire Groq (or Groq’s material assets/IP) with value >= $10B (stated or reported by Reuters/Bloomberg/WSJ/FT citing deal terms). Otherwise NO.
evidence: CNBC reports Nvidia is buying Groq assets for about $20B and licensing its tech (2025-12-24).
monitoring_signals: Nvidia investor relations press releases/8-K filings referencing Groq
Groq corporate statements on strategic transactions
Major deal reporters (Reuters/Bloomberg/WSJ/FT) confirming signed terms and valuation
predictions.rationale: A high-specificity rumor suggests advanced talks; the key uncertainty is whether it becomes a signed, announced deal versus exploratory discussions or a narrower licensing arrangement.

predictions.text: BP will close (complete) the announced sale of a 65% stake in Castrol to Stonepeak (or named buyer group) by 2026-09-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if BP publicly confirms completion/closing of the transaction (press release, RNS, 6-K/8-K, earnings release) on or before the deadline. NO if not closed by the deadline or if the deal is terminated.
evidence: CNBC reports BP plans to sell 65% of its ~$10B Castrol unit to Stonepeak (2025-12-24).
monitoring_signals: BP deal timeline updates in quarterly results
Regulatory approval updates (competition/FDI) in relevant jurisdictions
Buyer financing announcements and closing-condition disclosures
predictions.rationale: Portfolio sales of this type typically close within 6–12 months but can slip on regulatory approvals and financing/structure complexity.

predictions.text: Harvard University (or its governing corporation) will file a federal lawsuit against the U.S. executive branch or a federal agency related to the ongoing dispute (e.g., funding conditions, oversight demands, or regulatory leverage) by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a complaint is filed in U.S. federal court by Harvard (or an affiliated Harvard entity) naming a federal agency/official as defendant and the case is publicly docketed (PACER) by the deadline, clearly tied to the reported dispute. Otherwise NO.
evidence: NYT reports escalation in a high-stakes dispute between Harvard and the Trump administration (2025-12-24).
monitoring_signals: Harvard statements indicating imminent litigation
Federal agency actions affecting Harvard funding/conditions
PACER filings and major legal-news coverage (Reuters/WSJ)
predictions.rationale: Escalating federal leverage campaigns against institutions often culminate in injunctive/APA litigation; timing depends on concrete agency action that creates standing and urgency.

predictions.text: The U.S. Department of Justice Office of Inspector General will publicly announce (press release, report, or formal notice) a review/investigation into the handling, redaction, or release process for the Epstein-related document disclosures by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if DOJ OIG publicly states it has opened/initiated a review, audit, or investigation specifically referencing the Epstein document release/redaction issues by the deadline. Otherwise NO.
evidence: CNBC reports DOJ released more Epstein files and uncovered >1M additional potential records (2025-12-24).
NYT reports some DOJ redactions in Epstein documents are reportedly recoverable (2025-12-23).
monitoring_signals: DOJ OIG announcements and semiannual reports
Congressional letters requesting OIG involvement
DOJ internal policy updates on redaction/records handling
predictions.rationale: Operational-security and redaction failures with intense political scrutiny frequently trigger OIG review, but OIG prioritization and jurisdictional questions add uncertainty.

predictions.text: Amazon will launch a broadly available (not invite-only) AI shopping-agent feature in the U.S. that can autonomously perform multi-step shopping tasks (e.g., search/compare/select and complete checkout on behalf of a user) by 2026-09-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if Amazon publicly announces and makes available to U.S. customers (web/app) an AI agent explicitly designed to autonomously execute multi-step shopping flows beyond simple Q&A/recommendations, with rollout described as generally available or broadly available (not limited beta). Otherwise NO.
evidence: CNBC describes Amazon’s strategic dilemma regarding AI shopping agents that could disintermediate storefronts (2025-12-24).
monitoring_signals: Amazon Shopping and Alexa feature announcements
Public documentation/help pages describing agentic checkout capabilities
Third-party testing reports confirming autonomous task execution
predictions.rationale: Competitive pressure from agentic commerce makes an Amazon-native solution likely; the main uncertainty is legal/UX risk around delegated purchasing and merchant relationships.

predictions.text: At least one large U.S. investor-owned utility will publicly announce (press release, IRP filing, or earnings materials) a delay of a previously scheduled coal unit retirement by at least 24 months, explicitly citing new or expected federal policy support for coal plant retention, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if a U.S. investor-owned utility announces a coal-fired generating unit retirement date moving later by >=24 months versus its prior published plan, and the announcement explicitly references federal policy support from the administration (or federal actions) as a reason. Otherwise NO.
evidence: NYT reports Trump administration policy support to slow coal-plant closures, complicating transition economics (2025-12-24).
monitoring_signals: Integrated Resource Plans and state commission filings
Utility earnings calls citing federal coal-retention support
DOE/FERC emergency reliability actions involving coal
predictions.rationale: Utilities periodically revise IRPs; credible federal incentives or reliability directives can shift retirement economics, but state regulators and fuel/maintenance realities may limit reversals.

predictions.text: The U.S. and Honduras will announce a new bilateral migration/security cooperation package totaling at least $100 million in pledged funding and/or equipment support by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if the U.S. government (State/White House/DHS/DoD) and/or Honduras’ government publicly announces a new cooperation package explicitly tied to migration management and/or security cooperation with total value >= $100M (funding, equipment, or combined) by the deadline. Otherwise NO.
evidence: NYT reports Honduras declares Nasry Asfura president, implying potential shift in U.S. alignment and regional cooperation (2025-12-24).
monitoring_signals: State Department and DHS bilateral announcements
Foreign Military Financing (FMF) or security assistance notifications
Joint communiqués following high-level visits
predictions.rationale: Political realignment can unlock U.S. packages, but funding depends on U.S. congressional appropriations, regional priorities, and Honduran domestic politics.

predictions.text: Ukraine and Russia will hold at least one publicly confirmed direct in-person meeting between official delegations (not solely via intermediaries) that explicitly includes discussion of a demilitarized zone and/or troop pullbacks in eastern Ukraine by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if reputable outlets (Reuters/AP/AFP/FT/WSJ) or official statements confirm an in-person meeting between official Ukrainian and Russian delegations by the deadline where agenda includes demilitarized zone and/or troop pullbacks. Otherwise NO.
evidence: NYT reports Zelensky signals openness to pulling back troops in eastern Ukraine for a peace deal (2025-12-24).
monitoring_signals: Announcements of peace talks hosted by third countries
Public readouts mentioning DMZ/troop withdrawal terms
UN/OSCE involvement signals and envoy travel
predictions.rationale: Public signaling may precede talks, but domestic constraints and battlefield dynamics make direct meetings on territorial-security arrangements uncertain.

predictions.text: At least one major academic publisher (Elsevier, Springer Nature, Wiley, Taylor & Francis, IEEE) will announce a mandatory AI-use disclosure requirement embedded in manuscript submission for all journals (e.g., required checkbox/field) by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if any listed publisher publicly announces (policy post, author guidelines update, submission-system notice) a mandatory disclosure field/checkbox for AI tool use that applies publisher-wide (or across a clearly stated large portfolio) by the deadline. Otherwise NO.
evidence: ScienceDaily summary: studies suggest AI boosts paper output while average quality slips, raising concerns for evaluation and peer review integrity (2025-12-25).
monitoring_signals: Publisher-wide research integrity policy updates
Submission platform (Editorial Manager/ScholarOne) requirement changes
Retraction watch and publisher statements on AI screening
predictions.rationale: Publishers face rising volume and integrity pressure; moving from guidance to mandatory disclosure is a plausible near-term governance response, though implementation coordination can delay rollout.
